terms.definition: A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to access previous versions and maintain a history of revisions.
Computer-Aided Design - software used to create precise technical drawings and 3D models for engineering and manufacturing purposes.
Product Lifecycle Management - a system that manages product data and processes throughout the entire lifecycle from conception to disposal.
A single, unified storage location where all documents and files are kept, making them easily accessible to authorized users from one place.
The ability for multiple users to work on the same document simultaneously, seeing changes instantly as they are made by other team members.
Detailed documents that outline the requirements, features, materials, and performance criteria for a product or system.
Groups of people with different functional expertise working together toward a common goal, such as engineers, designers, and manufacturing specialists.
A chronological record of all changes, access, and activities performed on documents or systems, used for compliance and accountability purposes.
The process of ensuring that products and processes meet all applicable laws, regulations, and industry standards such as FCC, CE, or RoHS.
Federal Communications Commission - a U.S. agency that regulates electronic devices to ensure they don't cause harmful interference.
Restriction of Hazardous Substances - a European directive that restricts the use of certain hazardous materials in electrical and electronic equipment.
Conformité Européenne - a certification mark indicating that a product complies with European Union safety, health, and environmental protection standards.
Changes or modifications made to original design documents, drawings, or specifications during the product development process.
Documents that record the results of testing early versions of a product, including performance data, issues found, and recommended improvements.
A sequence of processes or steps that work must pass through from initiation to completion, often automated in documentation management systems.
